text: In Problem 1.1, students used ratios to determine which recipe was the most “orangey.”
Some students used a part-to-part ratio and others used a part-to-whole ratio. Recall from the Comparing Quantities Unit that:
A part-to-part ratio
2 cups of concentrate to 3 cups of water
2 cups concentrate : 3 cups water
It compares one part (the concentrate) to the other part (the water) in the whole (the juice).
Part-to-whole ratio
2 cups of concentrate to 5 cups of juice
2 cups concentrate : 5 cups juice
It compares one part (the concentrate) to the whole (the juice).
Stella’s group used unit rates. Recall that a unit rate is a specific kind of ratio where one of the quantities being compared is 1 unit. Every ratio has two unit rates.
Stella and Elise used part-to-part comparisons to write unit rates:
3 cups of water to 2 cups of concentrate can be written as
1 cup of water to 2/3 cups of concentrate
or
3/2 cups of water to 1 cup of concentrate.
Dan used part-to-whole comparison to write a unit rate:
2 cups of concentrate for 5 cups of juice can be written as
1 cup of concentrate for 5/2 cups of juice
or
2/5 cup of concentrate for 1 cup of juice
